awd_titl_txt: Identifying the Community Cultural Wealth of Successful Black Science Students through Participatory Action Research
awd_abstract_narration:
Black students persist in undergraduate science degree programs at a lower rate than all other racial and ethnic groups. Many of the barriers that Black students face in science programs have been identified.  However, a major shortcoming of prior research is a lack of focus on the strengths that Black students use to succeed in science. To address attrition of Black students in science, it is critical to understand not only the barriers they face, but also the mechanisms by which academically successful Black students complete undergraduate science degrees. This IUSE Exploration and Design research project will use a participatory action research approach to investigate the strengths of academically successful Black undergraduate science majors. Research results will be widely-disseminated to raise awareness of Black students' community cultural wealth, which is the knowledge, skills, abilities, and contacts that they use for educational success. This qualitative study will help to build a foundation for testing hypotheses about Black students' community cultural wealth, thus contributing to the national need to study critical issues in undergraduate STEM education.

The overall goal of this research project is to understand the persistence of Black students in earning undergraduate science degrees. To achieve this goal, a team of faculty and undergraduate researchers will collaborate to examine the mechanisms Black students use to succeed in their undergraduate science majors. The aims of this project are to: (1) investigate the capital, knowledge, skills, abilities, and contacts used by Black science majors; and (2) raise faculty awareness of the community cultural capital that successful Black students draw upon. The capital that Black science majors use to succeed will be characterized at a doctoral university (University of Georgia) and a college that primarily awards associate degrees (East Georgia State College). Research results will be used to create a student-led workshop for raising faculty awareness of the capital Black students bring to their science majors. It is expected that this awareness will help faculty to better support Black students' persistence in earning undergraduate science degrees.  This awareness may also contribute to more effective faculty support for all students. The workshop will also help address implicit bias, the unconscious attitudes and stereotypical opinions people have against certain groups of people.  This project seeks to contribute to a diverse, globally competitive STEM workforce by characterizing the community cultural wealth that Black students bring to their undergraduate science majors and by determining actions for raising awareness of this capital.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
We used an asset-based approach to investigate the strengths of academically successful Black undergraduate science majors using the community cultural wealth (CCW) framework. CCW focuses on the unique strengths and assets students of color bring to their education including "knowledge, skills, abilities and contacts" (Yosso, 2005, p. 77). We used a participatory action research (PAR) approach in acknowledgment of Black science majors' critical expertise about their own persistence. In PAR, researchers collaborate with members from the marginalized group being studied to do research with them, rather than on them. Using PAR, researchers investigate a social phenomenon and then use the evidence to take action to address challenges and highlight opportunities that emerged from the research. We formed a community of scholars that included 2 faculty of color collaborating with 10 Black undergraduate and 2 Black graduate co-researchers, who were all science majors. We mentored student co-researchers to lead all aspects of study design, data collection, data analysis, and dissemination. Together we studied 52 academically successful Black undergraduate science majors to understand how they succeeded in the face of systemic racism and other forms of oppression. Participants were recruited from three public institutions: an associate's college, a 4-year baccalaureate college, and a research university.

We found that Black undergraduate science majors are deeply called to pursue careers in science to serve their chosen families and communities, which helped them persist despite enormous stress, including the stress of anti-black racism (Means et al., 2022). Black science majors in our study used novel forms of capital including spiritual capital, such as prayer, and linguistic capital, such as singing, to uplift themselves during difficult times (Breeden et al., 2023). Black science majors also used navigational capital to create their own paths to science careers when the paths commonly used by other students were blocked to them. Black science majors used several forms of resistant capital to challenge the racial microaggressions they routinely experienced in their science majors (Stanton et al., 2022). Black science majors in our study also created formal and informal spaces where they could thrive, referring to a "silent code" to help one another succeed in science (Stanton et al., 2022). Co-researchers used these findings to by creating PAR products to help science faculty address racial inequities.

Our primary PAR product was an interactive implicit bias workshop for science faculty. Student co-researchers collaborated with the Vice Provost for Institutional Diversity and the Director for the Center for Teaching and Learning to create an interactive workshop, which featured results from our research. The main goal of their workshop was to help science faculty enhance their teaching, advising, and mentoring to better support Black students in science. After giving the workshop for over 60 science instructors at University of Georgia (UGA), student co-researchers professionally recorded their workshop as 5 short online modules that are now being used by faculty outside of UGA. Undergraduate co-researchers also initiated the development of additional PAR products. For example, co-researchers formed an advisory board to guide science faculty who were developing racial noticing training for faculty to ensure the scenarios used in the program were authentic to the experiences of students from racially marginalized groups. Our PAR products were designed to amplify Black students' success and encourage faculty to change science learning environments.

In addition to sharing our PAR products, we have disseminated the results of this project in 8 conference talks, 4 invited research seminars, 1 keynote address, 3 American Educational Research Association (AERA) conference papers, and 3 published papers (Breeden et al., 2023; Means et al., 2022; Stanton et al., 2022). This project has contributed to a diverse, globally competitive STEM workforce by raising awareness of the strengths Black undergraduates bring to their science majors and changing the science learning environments they are succeeding in.
